snippet.title: RUSSIA: AUTHORITIES CRACK DOWN ON AMBER SMUGGLING
snippet.description:
(30 Nov 1995) Russian/Nat

The authorities in Russia are cracking down on amber smuggling. 

Hundreds of tons of amber are coming into the country illegally from the Russian enclave of Kaliningrad on the Baltic coast.

Ninety per cent of the world's amber supply comes from the Baltic shores -- and all it takes to collect the precious gems is a water jet and a shovel.

Kaliningrad -- once controlled by the Nazis -- is now Russia's main source of amber.

The naval outpost on the Baltic coast has huge reserves of the golden gem.

But economic hardship and flourishing crime mean that much of it is smuggled illegally into Russia.

While an estimated 650 tons a year is delivered to the factory in the town of Amber -- at least 300 tons is smuggled illegally over the border to mainland Russia. 

SOUNDBITE: (Russian)
Interests of the state should be upheld. But they can be upheld through various means and our proposal is that the state should reserve the right to own minerals separated from rock mass.
SUPER CAPTION:  Aleksei Khan, director amber factory

Hundreds of people, left unemployed by cutbacks in military spending after the end of the Cold War, now survive by digging for the material.  

They earn around 20 to 30 U-S dollars per day. 

That's a small fortune compared with the average Russian monthly salary of 100 USD. 

But the job is hazardous. 

The local Interior Ministry department makes regular raids on the amber fields, confiscating equipment and forcing the diggers to fill in the deep holes they have dug. 

SOUNDBITE: (Russian)
There are fences who will pay good money for the amber, but the majority of the diggers just do it to get some money to buy vodka. But with all this digging people can die in mud slides. Last summer we found the body of a fourteen-year old.
SUPER CAPTION: Lt Pyotr Ivankov, Kaliningrad police

But local crime officials say the punishments are ineffective. 

The most these men will receive is a heavy fine. They'll probably be back again tomorrow -- searching for amber to pay the fine.
